Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Situation2: A life-support device in the intensive care unit is flashing critical fault codes.
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from my younger brother: “Hey, are you still coming to the movies tonight? Everyone’s waiting for you!” I smiled, remembering our promise to spend more time together, to make up for the years we’d drifted apart. I wanted to be there, to show him he mattered, to build the kind of mutual respect we’d both longed for. But just as I was about to reply, my pager shrieked—an emergency call from the hospital. A life-support device in the ICU was flashing critical fault codes. I was the only machine repairer on call tonight, and the staff needed me to diagnose and fix the issue immediately. My heart pounded as I stared at my brother’s hopeful message and the urgent hospital alert. I felt torn in two, the weight of my family’s expectations pressing against the life-or-death responsibility of my job. I stood frozen, wrestling with the impossible choice between being the sister my brother needed and the professional my patients depended on.
